	ITEM&nbsp;10.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<A NAME="D135598D20F_HTM_TOC135598_43">
</A>
	10.A Share Capital
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Not applicable.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<A NAME="D135598D20F_HTM_TOC135598_44">
</A>
	10.B Memorandum and Articles&nbsp;of Association
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	I. General
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We are registered in the
	Istanbul Trade Registry under number 304844. Pursuant to Article&nbsp;3&nbsp;of our Articles&nbsp;of Association, as amended on January&nbsp;30, 2009, at the Extraordinary General Assembly, we are incorporated primarily for the provision of any
	telephone, telecommunication and similar services in compliance with the Telegraph and Telephone&nbsp;Law number 406&nbsp;and services stated in the GSM Pan Europe Mobile Telephone&nbsp;System bid that was signed with the Ministry of Transport,
	Maritime Affairs and Communications and to operate within the authorization regarding the IMT-2000/UMTS services and the infrastructure.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	II. Board
	Members
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	a.
</B>
<B>
<I>
	General
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	According to our Articles&nbsp;of Association, the Board of Directors is comprised of seven&nbsp;members elected by the general assembly. An
	increase in the number of members of the Board of Directors must be approved by the general assembly. However, in a series of resolutions in&nbsp;2013, the CMB appointed new members to our Board, who shall remain members until new members are
	elected or until the CMB announces a new resolution. With the new Turkish Commercial Code Act number 6102&nbsp;(&#147;TCC&#148;), which came into force on July&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2012, the requirement of having a share of company in order to become a
	member of Board of Directors has been abolished. The individuals who do not have any&nbsp;shares in the company have been provided an opportunity to be elected as members of the Board of Directors and carry out such duty. Additionally, the TCC
	mandated that the Board members who have been elected as a representative of a legal entity be required to resign and that the new Board members (as individuals or representatives of the legal entity) be required to be appointed in their place until
	October&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2012&nbsp;at the latest. Currently none&nbsp;of the directors on our Board are either representatives of shareholders that are legal entities or shareholders themselves.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The TCC does not require a Board member to be a Turkish citizen. There is no minimum age for the directors, provided that a Board member has
	reached the age of majority, which is 18, and there is no mandatory retirement age under applicable law. The conditions to be a Board member are regulated by the new TCC and the conditions to be an independent board member are regulated by the
	related CMB legislation.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	b.
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Board Members&#146; Interest
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The TCC forbids a Board member to enter into a transaction with us in any area relating to business, either on the Board member&#146;s own
	behalf or on behalf of someone&nbsp;else, thus preventing the abuse of duty by Board members and protecting our interests (TCC Article&nbsp;395)&nbsp;without the authorization of the general assembly. Our general assembly may authorize our Board
	members to enter into these types of transactions through a specific provision in our Articles&nbsp;of Association, or our general assembly may grant such a right on a&nbsp;yearly basis.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	108
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage112"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D135598D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Interested Board members cannot participate in and sign such resolutions. If we suffer any loss
	because of a Board member&#146;s failure to raise such an issue, the Board member shall be held liable to compensate us for the loss incurred due to such matters related to relatives.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Under TCC Article&nbsp;396, without the authorization of the general assembly, the Board members are barred from participating in similar
	commercial activities outside our Company. Board members cannot become shareholders with unlimited liability or become Board members of companies active in similar types of business. A specific provision in our Articles&nbsp;of Association or our
	general assembly may grant such a right on a&nbsp;yearly basis.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Furthermore, based on the Corporate Governance Communiqu&eacute; numbered
	II-17.1, which was published in the Official Gazette dated January&nbsp;3,&nbsp;2014, replacing the previous regulatory framework, in cases where shareholders having a management control, members of the board of directors, managers with
	administrative liability and their spouses, or relatives by blood or marriage up to second degree, conduct a significant transaction with the company or its subsidiaries which may cause a conflict of interest, and/or conduct a transaction on behalf
	of themselves or a third party, which is in the field of activity of the company or its subsidiaries, or become an unlimited shareholder to a corporation which operates in the same field of activity as the company or its subsidiaries, such
	transactions need to be included in the general assembly agenda as a separate item for providing detailed information at the general assembly meeting on the matter and need to be recorded in the minutes of the meeting.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	c.
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Compensation
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Any remuneration payable to Board members in relation to their Turkcell board membership shall be determined by our general assembly. The Board
	of Directors has no authority to determine such remuneration. At our Annual General Assembly held on April&nbsp;29, 2010, it was decided that our Chairman would receive a net sum of &#128;250,000&nbsp;per&nbsp;year and each Board member would
	receive a net sum of &#128;100,000&nbsp;per&nbsp;year for the period of their service, effective February&nbsp;25, 2010.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	According to a
	CMB Communiqu&eacute; Serial: IV, No: 56&nbsp;Concerning the Establishment and Implementation of the Corporate Governance Principles, which was published in the Official Gazette dated December&nbsp;30, 2011, a written&nbsp;Remuneration Policy for
	Board members and senior management was prepared. This Policy was posted on the company&#146;s website and submitted at the Annual General Assembly as a separate agenda item for information. The Corporate Governance Communiqu&eacute; numbered
	II-17.1, which was published in the Official Gazette dated January&nbsp;3,&nbsp;2014&nbsp;and replaced the Communiqu&eacute; Serial: IV, No: 56, kept this requirement as a mandatory corporate governance principle dealing with Financial Rights of
	Board Members and Executives Having Administrative Responsibility. The Annual General Assembly meeting of our Company pertaining to the years 2010, 2011, 2012, 2013 and 2014 has been convened on March&nbsp;26, 2015. The same item was on the agenda
	for the Annual General Assembly meeting held in 2015 and shareholders have been informed. Payment plans such as stock options or those based on company performance are not used in the remuneration of independent Board members. Remuneration of
	independent board members must safeguard the independency level.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	d.
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Borrowing Power
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	To the extent the relevant provisions of Turkish law allow, the Board of Directors of our Company&nbsp;is the body entitled to, directly or
	through representatives authorized by the Board of Directors, resolve to exercise our powers to borrow money or give any form of guarantee or surety relating to our or any third party&#146;s obligations. The CMB adopted a rule&nbsp;on
	September&nbsp;9, 2009, which was announced in its weekly bulletin in connection with credit extensions, that public companies can provide guarantees or pledges, including mortgages, to third parties, provided such third party (i)&nbsp;is fully
	consolidated in the company&#146;s financial statements or (ii)&nbsp;the ordinary business operations of the company directly requires providing guarantees, pledges or mortgages. At the Ordinary General Assembly held on April&nbsp;29, 2010,
	Article&nbsp;3&nbsp;entitled Purpose and Subject Matter of Turkcell&#146;s Articles&nbsp;of Association was amended in line with CMB&#146;s rule&nbsp;dated September&nbsp;9, 2009. Under our Articles&nbsp;of Association, our Board of Directors is
	authorized to issue debentures and other securities subject to the TCC, Turkish Capital Markets Law and other relevant legislation. Under Turkish Capital Markets Law, the total value of capital market instruments shall not exceed the amount
	specified by the CMB, for each type of instrument. However, as a general rule, the total value of debentures and other debt instruments that a publicly held company may issue as capital market instruments may not exceed the balance remaining after
	deducting the losses, if any, from the total sum of the outstanding and paid-up capital as shown on the latest independently audited financial statements submitted to the CMB, plus reserves and the revaluation fund stated in the latest financial
	statement approved by the general assembly. Pursuant to Article&nbsp;3&nbsp;of our Articles&nbsp;of Association, as amended on October&nbsp;2, 2009&nbsp;at the Extraordinary General Assembly, and as effective on
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	109
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage113"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D135598D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	October&nbsp;7, 2009, we can extend credits to companies in which we have direct or indirect shareholding interest, both in Turkey and overseas, as well as to our main company and group
	companies, in Turkish Lira or other foreign currencies, on the condition that such extensions do not conflict with applicable laws and regulations. In addition, the TCC similarly allows group companies to extend credits and guarantees to each other
	without abusing their authority The Corporate Governance Communiqu&eacute; numbered II-17.1, which was published in the Official Gazette dated January&nbsp;3,&nbsp;2014, incorporated the rule&nbsp;which was announced in its weekly bulletin on
	September&nbsp;9, 2009&nbsp;in its Article&nbsp;12. Furthermore, as per Article&nbsp;12, board resolutions with regard to providing guarantees or pledges including mortgages within the framework of ordinary business operations of the company should
	be signed by the majority of independent board members. In case the majority of independent board members do not approve the resolution, dissenting opinions should be announced to the public. In such resolutions, related board members, if any, could
	not participate to the relevant board meeting.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	e.
</B>
<B>
<I>
	CMB Rules
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	&nbsp;
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Regarding Transactions with
	Related Parties
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Initially, based on the CMB Communiqu&eacute; Serial&nbsp;IV, No.&nbsp;56, dated December&nbsp;30, 2011,
	the approval of the majority of the independent members was necessary for any and all kinds of related party transactions of the company (related parties referred in the Communiqu&eacute; will be determined in accordance with the Turkish Accounting
	Principles No.&nbsp;24, equivalent of IAS 24), as well as for the resolutions of the board of directors with respect to giving guarantees, pledges and mortgages in favor of third parties. The CMB in a further announcement clarified that listed
	companies could adopt one&nbsp;board/general assembly resolution for the execution of transactions of a continuous and extensive nature with related parties unless the terms of those transactions had changed. In the event such changes occur, new
	board/general assembly resolutions will be needed. The new Capital Markets Law dated December&nbsp;30, 2012&nbsp;empowered the CMB to determine the nature of such transactions. Accordingly, the CMB with its Communiqu&eacute; Serial IV,
	No.&nbsp;63&nbsp;dated February&nbsp;22,&nbsp;2013 restricted the scope and set out that only material related party transactions, as opposed to all kinds of transactions, shall be submitted to the approval of independent members. In cases where the
	majority of the independent members do not approve such material transaction, the case shall be disclosed to the public in a manner covering sufficient information with respect to the transaction within the scope of public disclosure arrangements,
	and the transaction shall be submitted to the general assembly for approval. During such general assembly meetings, a resolution shall be adopted by vote in which the parties to the transaction as well as the individuals related thereto are not
	entitled to vote. Meeting quorum shall not be necessary for the general assembly meetings to be held for those cases. Such resolutions shall be adopted by simple majority of the attendees having the right to vote. The Company&nbsp;shall incorporate
	related mandatory provisions of the said Communiqu&eacute; in its Articles&nbsp;of Association (along with other mandatory provisions relating to corporate governance, see &#147;Item&nbsp;16.G. Corporate Governance&#148;). The Corporate Governance
	Communiqu&eacute; numbered&nbsp;II-17.1, which was published in the Official Gazette dated January&nbsp;3,&nbsp;2014, defined the materiality as set out by the Communiqu&eacute; Serial IV, No.&nbsp;63. Accordingly, a 10% threshold will be applied in
	comparison with the relevant criteria such as total annual assets, annual revenues or market value of the company. When a transaction&#146;s amount is above this 10% threshold, the majority vote of independent board members will be sought.
	Additionally, in order to ensure internal compliance with the CMB&#146;s related party transactions, our Board has adopted the &#147;Rules to be Applied to Related Parties in Purchasing/Selling Assets and Services along with Transfers of
	Liabilities&#148; to be applied by the relevant employees within the company and its group companies on November&nbsp;22, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	III. Capital Structure
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	a.
</B>
<B>
<I>
	General
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our Board of Directors has adopted the authorized share capital system which, under Turkish law, allows us to increase our issued share capital
	up to the authorized share capital amount upon resolution by our Board and without need for further shareholder approval. On January&nbsp;23, 2008, the CMB amended its Communiqu&eacute; on principles regarding the registered capital system.
	According to this amendment, the registered capital ceiling authorization given by the CMB shall be valid for five&nbsp;years, including the&nbsp;year in which the authorization is granted. As this five-year term ended in January&nbsp;23,&nbsp;2013,
	as done in 2014, the Company&nbsp;applied for the CMB&#146;s authorization in order to determine its capital ceiling for a five-year term between 2016 and 2020, and will amend its Articles&nbsp;of Association accordingly at the next ordinary general
	assembly meeting, which is expected to be held on March 29, 2016. In an effort to harmonize new legislation with the Capital Markets Law numbered 6362, which entered into force on December&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2012, the CMB released the Communiqu&eacute;
	on the Registered Capital System II-18.1&nbsp;which became effective on December&nbsp;25,&nbsp;2013. The new Communiqu&eacute; mostly includes regulations&nbsp;in line with the former Communiqu&eacute; (Serial: VI, No: 38)&nbsp;and de facto practice
	of the CMB. As for the determination of the ceiling, the new Communiqu&eacute; contemplates a limitation for the ceiling and states that the registered capital ceiling shall not be more than five&nbsp;times the issued capital or the equity,
	whichever is higher. The new Communiqu&eacute; also sets out that the
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	110
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage114"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D135598D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	registered capital ceiling may be exceeded once within the scope of each ceiling (i)&nbsp;through conversion of all kinds of internal resources and dividends into the share capital; and
	(ii)&nbsp;as a result of transactions requiring general assembly resolutions such as mergers and spin-offs. However, both the former legislation and the new Communiqu&eacute; provide that the registered capital ceiling may not be exceeded with
	capital increases through cash. As in the former regime, the registered capital ceiling approved by the CMB is valid for five&nbsp;years including the&nbsp;year in which the approval is granted. Upon the expiry of the term, even if the registered
	capital ceiling has not been reached, in order for the board of directors to adopt a capital increase resolution, the board of directors must obtain authorization for a new period at the first general assembly upon the approval of the CMB for the
	same ceiling or a new ceiling. The term of this authorization may be extended for five&nbsp;year periods through a general assembly resolution. In the event such authorization is not obtained, the new Communiqu&eacute; emphasizes that companies may
	not realize a capital increase through a board of directors&#146; resolution, whereas under the former Communiqu&eacute;, companies were deemed to be excluded from the registered capital system. The increase of the registered capital ceiling,
	extension of the permission period, capital increase and relevant resolutions of the board of directors shall be disclosed to the public within the framework of the CMB disclosure rules.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	b.
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Preemption Rights
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We may increase our capital only through the issuance of new&nbsp;shares, and such issuances may come in the form&nbsp;of a rights offering or
	a bonus issue. Under Turkish law, existing shareholders are entitled to subscribe for new&nbsp;shares, also known as preemption rights, in proportion to their respective shareholdings each time we undertake a capital increase. Our Board of Directors
	will generally recommend that new&nbsp;shares be issued at prices equal to their nominal value, which entitles the existing shareholders to subscribe for&nbsp;shares at a significant discount from their current market price. The exercise of
	preemption rights by shareholders must be made within a subscription period which we announce, which may not be less than 15 days nor more than 60 days after the issuance of the preemption rights circular. Shareholders who do not wish to subscribe
	for new&nbsp;shares may sell their rights on the Borsa Istanbul (&#147;BIST&#148;). Any&nbsp;shares not subscribed for by the existing shareholders or purchasers of the rights coupons are sold on the BIST at the current market price. Any differences
	between the rights issue price and the price realized for the&nbsp;shares on the BIST would accrue to our surplus account. Preemption rights of shareholders related to a rights offering may be restricted wholly or in part&nbsp;either by an
	affirmative vote of the holders of a majority of the outstanding&nbsp;shares at an ordinary or extraordinary general assembly or a resolution adopted by the Board of Directors to such effect, provided that such authority is conferred upon the Board
	of Directors. CMB rules&nbsp;stipulate that such authority may be conferred upon the Board of Directors of companies that have received permission from the CMB to adopt the authorized capital system. As per the new Communiqu&eacute; on the
	Registered Capital System II-18.1, the General Assembly shall approve the amendments to the articles&nbsp;of association with respect to granting authorization to the board of directors to restrict the pre-emptive rights of the shareholders to
	acquire new&nbsp;shares. Contrary to the former Communiqu&eacute;, the new Communiqu&eacute; has not foreseen a meeting quorum. With regard to the decision quorum, the former Communiqu&eacute; differentiated between companies making an initial
	public offering and public companies, whereas the new Communiqu&eacute; has not stipulated any such distinction. Accordingly, the new Communiqu&eacute; regulates that shareholders holding 2/3&nbsp;of the&nbsp;shares having voting rights shall
	provide affirmative votes. In addition, the new Communiqu&eacute; has prescribed that if at least shareholders holding half of the voting&nbsp;shares are present at the meeting, the decision quorum shall be the majority of the&nbsp;shares
	participating in the meeting.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	By the amendment to the Articles&nbsp;of Association, we have conferred such authority on our Board of
	Directors. The CMB further requires that the right of the Board of Directors to restrict the preemption rights of shareholders applies equally with respect to all shareholders. Under Turkish law, bonus issues may be undertaken in order to convert
	all or a portion of the revaluation fund and reserves of a company into share capital.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	c.
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Dividend Distribution and Allocation of Profits
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our Board of Directors recommends annual dividends, which then must be approved by our shareholders at their annual
	general assembly. Dividends are payable on a date determined at the annual general meeting. Under current rules, the Board of Directors may decide whether or not to recommend a distribution of dividends, and our shareholders at our annual general
	meeting may decide whether or not to distribute dividends in any&nbsp;year. According to new Capital Markets law, we may freely determine the amount of dividends to be distributed based on the Dividend Policy, pursuant to applicable Turkish laws and
	upon the approval of, or amendment by, the Board of Directors and the General Assembly of Shareholders. The Board decides whether or not to recommend an allocation of profits, as well as the amount of dividends, and the shareholders, through the
	general assembly, may accept, amend or reject such proposal, if any.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	111
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage115"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D135598D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The new dividend distribution regime is governed by a CMB Communiqu&eacute; on Dividends
	II-19.1&nbsp;which was published in the Official Gazette dated January&nbsp;23,&nbsp;2014, numbered 28891, which entered into force on February&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2014. Within the scope of the Communiqu&eacute;, companies shall distribute dividends
	through a general assembly resolution in accordance with current legislation and the policies of the company. As per the Communiqu&eacute;, dividends may be distributed in installments in case a general assembly resolution is adopted in this regard.
	The Communiqu&eacute; has also determined the principles and procedures for the distribution of dividends. The CMB allows public companies the possibility of choosing the timing and payment method of the dividend distribution on the condition that
	the company&#146;s own dividend policy should regulate this. In any case, according to the new Communiqu&eacute;, distribution should commence until the end of the financial&nbsp;year in which the general assembly decided on distributing a dividend.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In order to comply with this Capital Markets Board&#146;s Communiqu&eacute;, the Turkcell Board of Directors amended its dividend
	distribution policy proposal in February 2014, as stated below, and approved by the Ordinary General Assembly held on March&nbsp;26, 2015:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	&#147;The
	Company&nbsp;shall target a dividend payout of at least 50% of its distributable net income as cash. This policy will be subject to the Company&#146;s cash projections, business outlook, investment plans and capital market conditions. The actual
	dividend decision will be made for each fiscal&nbsp;year separately with the approval of the General Assembly of Shareholders. Dividend distribution shall be started on a date to be determined by the General Assembly of Shareholders which shall not
	be later than the end of the&nbsp;year in which the General Assembly convenes. The Company, in accordance with laws and regulations, may consider distributing advance dividends or making the dividend payment in equal or unequal installments.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Additionally, in order to create added value for its shareholders, the Company&nbsp;may also consider share repurchase programs depending on the
	conditions set forth above and applicable regulation.&#148;
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In parallel with the new Capital Markets Law, the new Communiqu&eacute;
	on Dividends sets ground rules for donations: articles of association of public companies should contemplate it and an annual limit should be determined by the general assembly. On February&nbsp;24, 2015, within the framework of the CMB regulations,
	our Board has resolved that, by means of determining the upper limit for the total amount of donations to be made by the Company within the year 2015 as up to 0.2% of our Company&#146;s revenue included in the annual consolidated financial tables
	relating previous fiscal year announced to the public pursuant to CMB regulations, this abovementioned upper limit is approved by General Assembly of our Company. On January 28, 2016, our Board of Directors has resolved to determine the upper limit
	for the total amount of donations to be made by our Company within the year 2016 as up to 1% of our Company&#146;s revenue as set forth in the annual consolidated financial statements for the previous fiscal year as announced to the public pursuant
	to Capital Markets Board regulations. This limit shall be submitted for the shareholders&#146; approval at the next General Assembly of our Company.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Dividends are payable by transfer to the account of the shareholders with a bank in Turkey corresponding to the relevant portion of
	their&nbsp;shares. Shareholders&#146; entitlement to cash dividends remains in effect for a period of five&nbsp;years following the date of the general assembly approving such distribution, after which time they are transferred to the Turkish
	government.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Part&nbsp;of our remaining net profit may be distributed to our shareholders as a second dividend or retained by us as
	retained earnings, all at the discretion of our general assembly.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For additional details regarding our dividend policy see
	&#147;Item&nbsp;8.A. Consolidated Statements and Other Financial Information&#151;Dividend Policy&#148;.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	d.
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Voting Rights
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Shareholders are entitled to one&nbsp;vote per share on all matters submitted to a vote of our shareholders.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	CMB Communiqu&eacute; Serial&nbsp;IV, No.&nbsp;56&nbsp;dated December&nbsp;30, 2011&nbsp;(see &#147;Item&nbsp;16.G. Corporate Governance&#148;
	for further information), initially stated that transactions considered as material (transfer, acquisition or lease of all or significant portion of company assets or constitution of limited property right there on; providing concession or changing
	content or subject of existing concessions and being delisted)&nbsp;under certain conditions those material transactions will need to be approved by the general assembly. In the event that parties to such transactions are related parties, such
	related parties shall not vote at the general assembly. The new Capital Markets law dated December&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2012&nbsp;further expanded the scope of &#147;material
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	112
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage116"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D135598D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	transactions&#148;, which were exhaustively enumerated by the aforementioned Communiqu&eacute; by adding the term &#147;like&#148; at the beginning of the enumeration. However, the topic has once
	again been regulated by another CMB Communiqu&eacute; Serial&nbsp;IV, No.&nbsp;63&nbsp;dated February&nbsp;22,&nbsp;2013, and the term of &#147;material transactions&#148; with regard to the implementation of Corporate Governance Rules&nbsp;is again
	exhaustively defined in parallel with the Communiqu&eacute; dated 2011.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The CMB issued the Communiqu&eacute; No.&nbsp;II-23.1&nbsp;on
	Common Principles Regarding Material Transactions and the Right of Separation (published in the Official Gazette dated December&nbsp;24,&nbsp;2013, No.&nbsp;28861). Material transactions of public companies are exhaustively enumerated. Some of the
	issues covered by the Communiqu&eacute; are listed below:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	procedures and principles applicable to the material transactions of publicly held companies;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	exercise of the right of separation in relation to the material transactions and the cases where the right of separation is not applicable;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	pricing of the right of separation in non-listed companies;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	mandatory tender offer in connection with the material transactions; and
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	mandatory meeting and decision quorums applicable to general assembly meetings with regard to material transactions.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	e.
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Transfer of Shares
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Subject to the limitations described below,&nbsp;shares may be sold and transferred by endorsement and delivery.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In practice,&nbsp;shares in registered form&nbsp;traded on the BIST are represented by the share certificates endorsed in blank, enabling
	such&nbsp;shares to be transferred as if they were in bearer form. As per the amendment in the then in force Capital Markets Law and a communiqu&eacute; issued by the CMB in this respect, our Company&#146;s&nbsp;shares traded at the Borsa Istanbul
	were dematerialized as of November&nbsp;2005.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Legal and actual dematerialization of the share certificates commenced on November&nbsp;28,
	2005. Beginning from November&nbsp;28, 2005, it is prohibited for companies registered on the ISE to issue new share certificates, in consideration of rights issues or bonus issues. The new&nbsp;shares arising out of capital increases shall be
	transferred to the accounts of the rightful owners by registration.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	A seven-year term given for the dematerialization of
	physical&nbsp;shares ended on December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2012&nbsp;and physical&nbsp;shares which were not delivered for dematerialization were supposed to become the property of the Company. However, according to the new Capital Markets Law which came
	into force on December&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2012, such undelivered physical&nbsp;shares are now transferred to the Investor Compensation Center and sold three&nbsp;months following the transfer on the Investor Compensation Center&#146;s accounts. However,
	the Turkish Constitutional Court in its decision published in the Official Gazette on November 12, 2015, nullified the provisions of the Capital Markets Law regarding the ownership transfer of such undelivered physical shares to the Investor
	Compensation Center on the ground that such language contradicted with Art. 13 (Restriction of fundamental rights and freedoms) and Art. 35 (Right to property) of the Constitution.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Concerning registration of share transfers, the Company&nbsp;will take into account the Central Registry Agency&#146;s data without requiring
	any application from the interested parties. Provisions regarding the nominal values of the share certificates of the Company&nbsp;are regulated in the temporary article&nbsp;of the Company&#146;s Articles&nbsp;of Association and such
	article&nbsp;was approved at the Ordinary General Assembly Meeting on April&nbsp;29, 2005. The temporary article&nbsp;reads as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Decree 32&nbsp;on the Protection of the Value of the Turkish Currency issued in August&nbsp;1989, as amended from time to time, provides that
	persons not resident in Turkey may purchase and sell our&nbsp;shares, provided that such purchase is effected through a bank or broker authorized pursuant to applicable Turkish capital markets legislation. Turkish capital markets legislation
	requires that&nbsp;shares of a company quoted on a Turkish securities exchange be traded exclusively on such exchange. The CMB has indicated that this requirement applies only to intermediary institutions licensed for trading on the stock exchange
	and to trade orders placed with them by investors. Accordingly, our shareholders that are not resident in Turkey may transfer such&nbsp;shares only on the ISE. This requirement does not apply to transfers of ADSs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Under Turkish law, in the event that one&nbsp;of our shareholders transfers&nbsp;shares to any other shareholder or to any other third party
	investor, either foreign or local, the Foreign Investment General Directorate (&#147;FIGD&#148;) must be notified within one&nbsp;month of the transfer of&nbsp;shares.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	113
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage117"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D135598D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Under Article&nbsp;8&nbsp;of the Electronic Communications Law, electronic communications
	services is rendered and/or electronic communications network or infrastructure is established and operated following the authorization made by the ICTA. Authorization is granted through the notification made in accordance with the principles and
	procedures determined by the ICTA, in case the resource allocation is not necessary, or given of usage right, in case the resource allocation, which means allocation of frequency, satellite position etc., is necessary. Furthermore, under the
	Authorization Regulation&nbsp;Regarding Telecommunication Services and Infrastructure Regulation, the ICTA must be notified in case of any share transfers within one&nbsp;month of the transfer of&nbsp;shares at the latest and in the event that the
	share transfer results in a change in control, such transfer of our&nbsp;shares by any of our shareholders should be realized with the written&nbsp;permission of the ICTA.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Under our Articles&nbsp;of Association, the Board of Directors is entitled to restrict the transfer of&nbsp;shares to foreigners in order to
	comply with Turkish shareholding requirements under Turkish law.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	f.
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Disclosure of Beneficial Interests in the Shares
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Turkish Regulation&nbsp;on public disclosure of listed companies was regulated by the CMB Communiqu&eacute; Serial VIII,
	No.&nbsp;54&nbsp;on Principles Regarding Public Disclosure of Material Events dated February&nbsp;2009. The CMB released a new Communiqu&eacute; on Public Disclosure of Material Events (II-15.1)&nbsp;which was published in the Official Gazette dated
	January&nbsp;23,&nbsp;2014, numbered 28891, which entered into force on February&nbsp;23,&nbsp;2014. Insider information, which means any non-public information that may possibly affect the value of capital market instruments and investors&#146;
	decisions, is required to be disclosed immediately by listed companies. Shareholders&#146; disclosure requirement would arise if they exceed the shareholding ratios established in the Communiqu&eacute;&nbsp;II-15.1&nbsp;(5%, 10%, 15%, 20%, 25%, 33%,
	50%, 67% and 95%). Disclosure of insider information may be delayed to protect the legitimate interests of the company without causing market manipulation. For those that have administrative responsibilities in Turkcell (including Board members and
	high-ranked executives), or are closely related persons, that purchase and sell Turkcell&#146;s capital market instruments (including, but not limited to, Turkcell&nbsp;shares), such transactions will need to be declared to the Borsa Istanbul;
	however, according to the Communiqu&eacute; II-15.1, if the cumulative amount of the above-mentioned Turkcell transactions does not exceed TL 50,000, such declaration will not be needed (TL&nbsp;100,000 for the company&#146;s securities other than
	shares). This upper limit represents the total amount of all transactions made by both Board members/high-ranked executives and their closely related persons of the company and that of its subsidiaries which represent more than 10% of the total
	assets according to the latest annual financial statements of the company. &#147;Closely related persons&#148; means: wives/husbands, children and individuals sharing the same residence at the time of transaction and corporations; legal entities run
	by, directly/indirectly controlled by or whose economic interests are similar with that of Board members; and high-ranked executives of the Company. The CMB by its decision dated June&nbsp;27, 2014 issued new guidelines for the announcement of
	material events for public companies based on Article&nbsp;27 of the Communiqu&eacute; II-15.1, thus repealing the old guidance which was prepared in conformity with the Communiqu&eacute; Serial VIII, No:54.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In addition, the CMB adopted a &#147;short-swing-profit rule&#148; for company executives. The CMB has published the Communiqu&eacute;
	No.&nbsp;VI-103.1&nbsp;Regarding Managers&#146; Payment of Net Purchase and Sale Gains to the Issuers (published in the Official Gazette dated December&nbsp;12,&nbsp;2013, No.&nbsp;28849). The Communiqu&eacute; VI 103.1&nbsp;relies on the Capital
	Markets Law Article&nbsp;103/4&nbsp;and indicates that (i)&nbsp;the board members and the committee members of an issuer, (ii)&nbsp;the persons with administrative responsibilities at the issuer and (iii)&nbsp;the persons that have the power to
	determine and control the issuer&#146;s financial and operational policies, decisions or targets directly or indirectly, shall pay the net gains they have obtained through the purchases and sales within the same six-month period. It is indicated in
	the Communiqu&eacute; VI 103.1&nbsp;that the purpose of this regulation&nbsp;is to remove the inequality of opportunity between the persons who receive insider information about the issuers easier and faster due to their positions and the investors
	that reach the insider information after public disclosure.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In addition, according to the Communiqu&eacute; on Voluntary and Mandatory
	Tender Offers (&#147;Communiqu&eacute; Serial IV No.&nbsp;44&#148;) issued by the CMB on September&nbsp;2, 2009, the mandatory tender offer shall be triggered when, directly or indirectly, more than 50% of our Company&#146;s shareholding is acquired
	or management control of a public company is taken over through acquiring (i)&nbsp;the necessary number of&nbsp;shares granting the right to elect or (ii)&nbsp;privileged&nbsp;shares allowing the nomination of the majority of the board of directors.
	Communiqu&eacute; Serial IV No.&nbsp;44&nbsp;also stipulates certain circumstances which will not trigger a mandatory offer, such as management control changes of the company by a voluntary tender offer and share transfers by privileged shareholders
	with management control or persons acting together resulting in a possession of more than 50% of the capital or voting rights. The new Capital Markets Law incorporates those rules&nbsp;under its relevant provisions. The
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	114
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage118"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D135598D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Communiqu&eacute; on Tender Offer (II-26.1)&nbsp;which repeals the Communiqu&eacute; Serial: IV No: 44&nbsp;was published by the Capital Markets Board in the Official Gazette dated
	January&nbsp;23,&nbsp;2014, numbered 28891, which entered into force on the date of its publication. Through the Communiqu&eacute;, the procedures and principles regarding mandatory and voluntary tender offers as a result of a change in management
	control have been regulated in compliance with the new Capital Markets Law No.&nbsp;6362. Moreover, the definition of management control has been regulated as the direct or indirect acquisition of more than 50% of the share capital or the voting
	rights individually or collectively. Holding more than fifty percent of the voting rights of a corporation directly or indirectly, alone or jointly with persons acting in concert, or regardless of such percentage, holding privileged shares enabling
	their holder to elect a simple majority of the total number of the members of the board of directors or to nominate for the said number of directors in the general assembly meeting, is considered and treated as an acquisition of control.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Communiqu&eacute; on Tender Offer (II-26.1) was modified on February&nbsp;27, 2015 and the following situation has been added amid cases
	where a mandatory tender offer will not be triggered. Following the purchase by a third party of a portion of the shares of a controlling shareholder, on the condition that this third party has 50% or less of voting rights of the company, should
	such third party share equally or less than the management control of the company with this controlling shareholder by virtue of a written agreement, this situation is not considered a trigger for a mandatory tender offer for this third party.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In parallel, the Capital Markets Law No. 6362 introduces a squeeze-out right: in the event the shareholding of a shareholder reaches a
	threshold, which shall be determined by secondary legislation of the CMB, such shareholder shall have the right to purchase&nbsp;the shares of the minority shareholders and the minority shall have the right to sell their&nbsp;shares. The CMB
	released the Communiqu&eacute; on Squeeze-Out Rights and Statutory Put Option Rights (II-27.1)&nbsp;on January&nbsp;2,&nbsp;2014&nbsp;in the Official Gazette numbered 28870, which became effective as of July&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2014. This Communiqu&eacute;
	was replaced with the Communiqu&eacute; II-27.2 which entered into force upon its publication in the Official Gazette dated November&nbsp;12, 2014 and numbered 29173 (the &#147;new Communiqu&eacute;&#148;). According to the Communiqu&eacute;
	II-27.1, if the controlling shareholder, directly or indirectly, holds at least 95% of the voting rights in a public company as a result of a mandatory tender offer or by any other means, the controlling shareholder has the right to squeeze out all
	other shareholders regardless of whether they hold privileged&nbsp;shares. As per the new Communiqu&eacute;, in the event that a shareholder holds at least 98% of the voting rights in a public company either as a result of a mandatory tender offer
	or by any other means, or if the controlling shareholder already satisfying this threshold acquires an additional share, the controlling shareholder will be entitled to the right to squeeze-out all other shareholders. Once the squeeze-out right
	arises, the remaining minority shareholders will be entitled to the right to sell-out their shares. The new Communiqu&eacute; also stipulates a transition period. Accordingly, the threshold of 95% shall continue to apply to squeeze-out rights that
	arose before December 31, 2014 and a new threshold of 97% shall apply to squeeze-out rights that will arise thereafter until December&nbsp;31, 2017. The new Communiqu&eacute; regulates the squeeze-out and the put option rights under the same
	provision. Accordingly, the controlling shareholder is obliged to make a public disclosure, if and when the controlling shareholders&#146; shareholding ratio reaches at least 98% of the voting rights or acquires additional shares to enhance its
	status. The remaining minority shareholders are entitled to exercise their sell-out rights within three&nbsp;months following the public disclosure. The three-month period is statutory and the sell-out rights of the minority shareholders shall
	expire at the end of such period. The minority shareholder willing to exercise its sell-out right shall notify the public company in writing of its request. The board of directors shall procure the preparation of a valuation report in order to
	determine the purchase price for the minority shares within one&nbsp;month upon the sell-out request. Upon application of the controlling shareholder for exercising the squeeze-out right, and approval of the board of directors about the fulfillment
	of the conditions for exercising the squeeze-out right, the company shall apply to the CMB for issuance of new shares to replace the cancelled ones. A delisting application to the relevant stock exchange is also required. All payment and settlement
	transactions shall be conducted via the Central Registration Agency. The controlling shareholder shall deposit the share purchase amount to the company&#146;s account, within three&nbsp;business days following the notification made by the company at
	the latest, and the company shall transfer such amount to the relevant minority shareholders&#146; account on the second succeeding business day to complete the share transfer transactions. As for the calculation of the purchase price, the purchase
	price during exercising of the squeeze-out right shall be equivalent to the average of the weighted daily stock market price within the 30-day period prior to the disclosure stating that the controlling shareholder has reached at least 98% of the
	voting rights or acquired additional shares for traded shares. The Communiqu&eacute; refers to a &#147;fair price&#148; for the exercise of the sell-out right. Accordingly, (i)&nbsp;the price determined for the squeeze-out right; (ii)&nbsp;the price
	determined per each share group through a valuation report; (iii)&nbsp;the price of a mandatory tender offer within the&nbsp;year preceding the public disclosure of control, if any; and (iv)&nbsp;the average of the weighted average prices on the
	exchange pertaining to the previous six&nbsp;months, previous&nbsp;year and previous five&nbsp;years shall be compared. The highest value shall be determined as the purchase price when the sell-out right is
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	115
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage119"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D135598D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	exercised. The controlling shareholder is required to make a public disclosure if and when (i)&nbsp;the voting rights held by it exceed or fall below 98% of the total voting rights in the
	company; or (ii)&nbsp;it acquires additional shares when it already holds 98% or more of the voting rights. Additionally, the controlling shareholder is also obliged to make a public disclosure, if and when it decides to exercise the squeeze-out
	right. The company as well is obliged to disclose the (i)&nbsp;squeeze-out right requests, the procedure of squeeze-out and the results of the squeeze-out; (ii)&nbsp;application of a sell-out right including the total number of shareholders making
	an application for exercising their sell-out rights, the percentages of their voting rights, and the total price to be paid for the exercised sell-out rights; (iii)&nbsp;the results of valuation reports for determining the share price and
	(iv)&nbsp;the results of exercising the sell-out right including information on the number of shareholders who have used such right and their voting right percentages and the voting right percentage of the controlling shareholder.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	g.
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Free Float Definition Rules
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	While 35.88% of our Company&nbsp;is listed on the stock exchange, the number of our Company&#146;s free floating&nbsp;shares as of
	March&nbsp;10,&nbsp;2016&nbsp;was 765,908,887.05 according to the &#147;Report on Free Float Ratios&#148; released by the Central Registry Agency in accordance with the Capital Markets Board&#146;s decision 21/655&nbsp;of July&nbsp;23, 2010, as
	amended by its decision 24/729&nbsp;of August&nbsp;18, 2010, and its free float ratio was 34.81%. The difference between these rates results from the exclusion of&nbsp;shares which are: i. held by a public entity, ii. held by the company&#146;s
	incorporators and its affiliates (companies subject to consolidation), iii. held by shareholders who may be a natural person or a corporate body and control at least 10% of the Company&#146;s capital, iv. held by a)&nbsp;the members of the
	Company&#146;s Board of Directors and the Board of Auditors, b)&nbsp;General Manager or executives who are equal to or superior to a general manager in terms of their powers and functions, c)&nbsp;senior executives who report to General Manager or
	executives who are equal to or superior to a general manager in terms of their powers and functions, v.&nbsp;owned by the savings funds or foundations of companies, vi. provided as equity capital pursuant to regulations&nbsp;applicable to the
	capital markets legislation or as a collateral in respect of a margin trading or as a collateral except the ones which are given as a collateral only for Central Depository Bank markets, vii.&nbsp;which are legally restricted and cannot be subject
	to purchase and sale, viii.&nbsp;prohibited, ix.&nbsp;&#147;seized&#148; in the definition of free float ratio. The difference may result from one&nbsp;or more situations described in the decision and it is not possible for our Company&nbsp;to know
	it.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	h.
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Trading Rules
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	According to the CMB Communiqu&eacute; II-17.1 on Corporate Governance, public companies whose shares are traded on the National Market, Second
	National Market and Collective Products Market of the exchange shall be divided into three groups in accordance with their systemic significance considering their market values and the market values of the shares in active circulation. The average
	of the closing prices in the second session of the last trading days of March, June, September and December and the rates of the shares in active circulation is the basis of the calculation of the market price and the price of the shares in active
	circulation. In cases where different share groups of the same company are traded on the exchange, all of such groups shall be taken into consideration. This calculation shall be made by the CMB each year in January to determine the groups in which
	the corporations are included and the list shall be published by the Board Bulletin. In this regard, the numerical thresholds to be used for grouping are set forth below:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	a) First group: Companies whose average market value is above TRY 3 billion and average market value in actual circulation is above TRY 750
	million;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	b) Second group: Companies among those excluded from the first group, the average market value of which is above TRY 1 billion
	and average market value in actual circulation is above TRY 250 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	c) Third group: Companies among those excluded from the first
	and second groups, the shares of which are traded on National Market, Second National Market and Collective Products Market.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	116
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage120"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D135598D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Accordingly, the CMB by its decision numbered 31/1080 and dated October&nbsp;30, 2014 determined the following
	thresholds and measures, which are effective as of January&nbsp;2, 2015:
</P>
